which are available for return to the designated depositors. If no claim is
made within ten (10) days after publication of such notice, the Treasurer shall
report this fact to the President and Board of Trustees who may, by motion,
transfer such funds to the General Corporate Fund of the Village and such funds
shall thereupon become the property of the Village.
   B.   In the event that there is no known address for the depositor or their
lawful assignee and said funds have been held by the Village for at least two
(2) years beyond the date necessary to effectuate the purposes for which the
deposits were made, the Village Treasurer shall give notice by publication
addressed to whom it may concern in the manner above provided and if no claim
is made within ten (10) days, the Treasurer shall report this fact to the
President and Board of Trustees who may, by motion, transfer such funds to the
General Corporate Fund of the Village and such funds shall thereupon become the
property of the Village. (Ord. 85-10-48, 10-15-85)
1-9-10: NO INTEREST TO ACCRUE ON SPECIAL FUNDS:
Funds or cash bonds paid to the Village to be held for escrow purposes under
any ordinance or regulation of the Village shall not bear interest and the
Village shall not be held to account for investment earnings, if any, on said
funds to the depositor thereof. (Ord. 87-8-18, 8-18-87)
1-9-11: INDEMNIFICATION OF THE VILLAGE TREASURER:
The Village shall indemnify and hold harmless the Village Treasurer from any
personal claims, judgments, damages or awards against him arising out of the
performance of the duties specified in this Code or the statutes of the State
of Illinois. Such indemnification shall extend to all costs and attorneys fees
arising out of the defenses of such claims. The indemnification provided herein
shall extend to all acts performed in good faith and in a prudent manner by
said treasurer but shall not extend to any willful or wanton misconduct or
purposeful violation of law. (Ord. 92-8-12, 8-18-92)
CHAPTER 10
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-10-1: Participation In Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund
1-10-2: Legal Opinions Of Village Attorney
1-10-3: Attorney For The Village
1-10-4: Prevailing Wage Rates For Public Works Construction
1-10-5: Indemnification Of Village Officials
1-10-1: PARTICIPATION IN ILLINOIS MUNICIPAL RETIREMENT FUND:
The Village of Riverwoods, Lake County, Illinois, does hereby elect to
participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, effective January 1,
1981, and the Village Clerk is hereby directed to promptly file a certified
copy of this Resolution with the Board of Trustees of the Illinois Municipal
Retirement Fund. (Res. 80-9-15, 9-22-1980)
Employee contributions to the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund shall be paid
by the Village on behalf of all of the employees enrolled in the Fund, and the
payment shall be made by reducing the amount of the gross earnings payable to
employees by the amount of the contributions and making payment of this amount
directly to the Fund. The payment of employee contributions provided shall be
effective for all compensation paid to employees beginning with March 1982.
(Res. 82-2-10, 2-15-1982)
The Board of Trustees of the Village does hereby elect to exclude from
participation in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund all officials and
employees in positions normally requiring performance of duty for less than one
thousand (1,000) hours per year. This exclusion shall apply only to officials
and employees who first occupy offices or positions under the Fund after
adoption of this Resolution. (Res. 82-3-11, 3-15-1982)
1-10-2: LEGAL OPINIONS OF VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
Except as directed at a regular or special meeting of the Board, the Village
Attorney shall not prepare written ordinances or resolutions nor render legal
opinions except as follows: The President or any member of the Board shall
transmit to the Clerk of the Village or person so designated a written request
to the Village Attorney which shall be in duplicate. The Village Clerk shall
retain the copy for his permanent files and transmit the original to the
Village Attorney. The Village Attorney shall transmit said legal opinion,
ordinance or resolution, as the case may be, to the Village Clerk, which copy
will be forwarded by the Village Clerk to the President and members of the
Village Board at his earliest convenience. (Ord. 100, 6-3-1964; amd. 1982 Code)
1-10-3: ATTORNEY FOR THE VILLAGE:
   A.   Appointment: The Attorney for the Village, an executive officer of the
Village, shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Duties: The Attorney for the Village shall:
      1.   Prosecute and defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity
to which the Village may be a party or in which it may be interested;
      2.   See to the enforcement of all judgments or decrees rendered in favor
of the Village;
      3.   Advise the President and Board of Trustees on all legal questions
affecting the Village whenever requested so to do by any Village official, and
reduce any such opinion to writing when requested by the President;
      4.   Institute and complete all special assessment proceedings authorized
by ordinance;
      5.   Draft ordinances, contracts, leases and other documents to which the
Village may be a party; and
      6.   Perform such other professional services incident to his office as
may be required by the Board of Trustees or any of its committees. (1982 Code)
1-10-4: PREVAILING WAGE RATES FOR PUBLIC WORKS CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Wage Rates Provided: To the extent and as required by "An Act
regulating wages of laborers, mechanics and other workers employed in any
public works by the State, County, City or any public body or any political
subdivision or by anyone under contract for public works", approved June 26,
1941, as amended, the general prevailing rate of wages in this locality for
laborers, mechanics and other workers engaged in construction of public works
coming under the jurisdiction of the Village is hereby ascertained to be the
same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction work in the Lake County
area as determined by the Department of Labor of the State of Illinois as of
June 1987, a copy of that determination being attached hereto and incorporated
herein by reference. The definition of any terms appearing in this Section
which are also used in the aforesaid Act shall be the same as in said Act.
   B.   Applied To Public Works Employment: Nothing herein contained shall be
construed to apply said general prevailing rate of wages as herein ascertained
to any work or employment except public works construction of this Village to
the extent required by the aforesaid Act.
   C.   The Village Clerk shall:
      1.   Publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested
party in the main office of the Village this determination of such prevailing
rate of wage.
      2.   Mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and to any
association of employers and to any person or association of employees who have
filed their names and addresses, requesting copies of any determination stating
the particular rates and the particular class of workers whose wages will be
affected by such rates.
      3.   Promptly file a certified copy of this Section with both the
Secretary of State and the Department of Labor of the State of Illinois.
      4.   Cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation within
the area a copy of this Section, and such publication shall constitute notice
that the determination is effective and that this is the determination of this
public body. (Ord. 87-6-13, 6-16-1987)
1-10-5: INDEMNIFICATION OF VILLAGE OFFICIALS:
   A.   In the event any Village officer or employee, including, but not
limited to, the Village President, Trustees, Village Clerk, members of boards
and commissions, police officers, firefighters and any other employee or
appointed or elected official acting within the scope of his/her prescribed
duties for the Village is caused to be sued, the Village agrees to defend,
indemnify and hold harmless the officials and employees against all injuries,
deaths, loss, damages, claims, patent claims, suits, liabilities, judgments,
settlements, costs and expense incurred, subject to any of the limitations set
forth in this Section.
   B.   The Village President and Village Attorney, on behalf of the Village
reserve the right to determine the final selection of legal counsel and
disposition of any claims or lawsuits brought against any Village official,
appointed or elected, or any of its employees, except in cases where the
Village President, members of the Board of Trustees, or the Village Clerk are
sued in their personal capacities, in which instance the members sued shall
have the right to concur in or disapprove the choice of legal counsel made by
the Village President and the Village Attorney.
It is further understood that any employee or elected or appointed official of
the Village agrees to cooperate in his/her defense, as required by his/her
appointed legal counsel; and failure to assist and cooperate in his/her defense
may result in a waiver and withdrawal of all the covenants and promises set
forth in this Section.
   C.   The provisions for defense and indemnification provided herein shall be
limited in dollar amount for judgments, costs, settlements and awards all
inclusive to the maximum dollar amount of the Village's self-insurance
retention. In the event there exists commercial insurance coverage of any kind,
said insurance shall be exhausted prior to application to the Village's self-
insured retention.
   D.   The provisions for defense and indemnification herein shall not apply
in cases where a court of competent final jurisdiction has found that a Village
officer or employee, otherwise entitled to such defense and indemnification
hereunder, has committed fraudulent, criminal or malicious acts or in cases
involving the recovery of salary, wages, or interest or penalties thereon
payable to any person by the Village.
   E.   Nothing contained herein is intended to or shall result in the waiver
of any immunity by the Village, its officers and employees by the operation of
the Local Government and Governmental Tort Immunity Act or any other statutes
of the Village to avail itself of all defenses provided by said immunity
statute on behalf of itself, its officers and employees. (Ord. 99-5-9, 5-18-
1999)
CHAPTER 11
VILLAGE ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS AND MEASURES
SECTION:
1-11-1: Introduction
1-11-2: Village Attorney to Review
1-11-3: Readings
1-11-4: Effective Date of Ordinances
1-11-5: Establishment of Fees
1-11-6: Professional Consultant Fees
1-11-1: INTRODUCTION:
All ordinances and resolutions shall be introduced to the Board in printed or
written form. All ordinances or resolutions which are submitted to the Board by
citizens shall be dated and signed by the citizen proposing same. Any citizen
may submit the reasons for proposing such measure in a separate written brief
statement, and may apply to the Board for permission to be heard with respect
to such resolution or measure, which permission may be granted by majority vote
of the whole Board. Such hearing shall be subject to the authority of the
presiding officer.
1-11-2: VILLAGE ATTORNEY TO REVIEW:
All proposed ordinances shall be prepared or examined by the Village Attorney
and bear his approval.
1-11-3: READINGS:
   A.   Except for emergency or extraordinary measures, ordinances shall not be
passed until they have been presented on two (2) separate days at regular or
special meetings of the Board subsequent to the date of introduction unless the
requirement of two (2) separate days shall be dispensed with by affirmative
votes of the majority of the members of the Board; provided, that such
requirement shall never be dispensed with on any ordinance making a grant,
renewal, or extension of a franchise or other special privilege.
   B.   At the time of introduction of an ordinance, the Village Clerk shall
read the title and briefly state the general nature of the ordinance. The
Village President or any member of the Village Board shall, however, have
authority to require the ordinance to be read in full at time of introduction.
Such reading shall not constitute a first reading unless by majority vote of
members present.
   C.   The ordinance shall then be referred to an appropriate person,
administrative body or the Attorney for the Village for report at the next
regular meeting, and shall also be put on the new business agenda for
consideration at said next regular meeting.
   D.   The Village Clerk shall distribute copies of the proposed ordinance to
the Village President, members of the Village Board and the Village Attorney at
least ten (10) days prior to said next regular meeting.
   E.   At a meeting subsequent to the first reading, any Trustee may move the
adoption of that ordinance. If the motion receives a second, the chairman of
the meeting shall direct the Village Clerk to call the roll of the Trustees and
record their oral vote and the ordinance shall have been adopted by a vote of
the majority of the Trustees present, unless a greater vote is required by law
or other ordinance.
1-11-4: EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCE:
Ordinances imposing a fine or making an appropriation are effective ten (10)
days after publication. Other ordinances are effective immediately unless the
ordinance specifies otherwise. (Ord. 100, 6-3-64)
1-11-5: ESTABLISHMENT OF FEES:
Whenever any provision of this Code provides for a fee or penalty, said
provision may be changed from time to time by the adoption of a fee schedule or
amendment thereto, without a specific amendment to any section of this Code.
(Ord. 89-9-11, 9-19-89)
1-11-6: PROFESSIONAL CONSULTANT FEES:
   A.   Any person (an "applicant") requesting consideration or action by the
Village, submitting applications to the Village, including but not limited to,
permit applications, seeking review of projects or permit applications by the
village, or otherwise seeking appearance before the Village board, Plan
Commission, Zoning Board of Appeals, or any other board, commission or
committee of the Village shall be required, whenever it is deemed necessary by
the director of community services to deposit sufficient funds necessary to
defray anticipated professional consultant expense to be incurred by the
Village related to the project, action, application, or appearance requested.
Professional consultant expenses shall include, but are not limited to, the
fees of the Village Attorney, Village Engineer, Village Ecologist, Village
Forester and all outside inspectors whose fees are charged to the Village by
other governmental agencies.
   B.   The Director of Community Services shall, upon receipt of a matter
which may or will require professional consultant services to be rendered or
utilized by the Village, whenever practicable make an estimate of the amount of
the cost of expected services based on the nature of the matter, its
complexity, the relative need for professional consultant advice and the
expected duration of processing the matter. The Director of Community Services
shall so notify the applicant in writing:
      1.   With the estimate of the necessary funds to defray all professional
consultant costs the village might incur in the course of reviewing the matter
submitted by the applicant.
      2.   With notice to the applicant that the application or matter shall
not thereafter be reviewed or acted upon unless and until said sum is received
by the village.
   C.   The Director of Community Services shall periodically review the funds
on deposit to ensure that adequate funds are available to satisfy all
professional statements referring to said matter, in addition to any
administrative fees as required from time to time by the Village Code or
village fee schedule. If the Director of Community Services determines that
sufficient funds are not available, he or she shall notify the applicant and
request a further amount to defray the anticipated additional costs in
accordance with the standards set forth in this section or as more particularly
set forth in the village fee schedule. The applicant shall be given fourteen
(14) days to deposit the additional funds. In the event said additional funds
are not deposited, the Village and its consultants shall take no further action
on the matter and shall so notify the applicant.
   D.   Upon conclusion of the matter and after all outstanding professional
consultant fees incurred by the Village for review of the matter have been
satisfied in full, the Director of Community Services shall cause any remaining
balance, if any, of the funds deposited by the applicant to be remitted to the
person who had deposited the funds. (Ord. 20-02-04, 2-4-2020)
CHAPTER 12
INSPECTION AND PHOTOCOPYING OF PUBLIC RECORDS
SECTION:
1-12-1: Definitions
1-12-2: Village Clerk Responsible
1-12-3: Time to Respond
1-12-4: Time and Place for Request for Records
1-12-5: Approval of Description of Village of Riverwoods
1-12-6: Exemptions
1-12-7: Appeal Period
1-12-8: Costs
1-12-9: Applicability to Records Received or Obtained Prior to July 1, 1984
1-12-10: Categorization of Records
1-12-11: Reveal of Exempt Records
1-12-12: Separability
1-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
COPYING: The reproduction of any public record by means of any photographic,
electronic, mechanical or other process, device, or means.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, partnership, firm, organization or
association acting individually or as a group, or any other legal entity.
PUBLIC BODY: Any legislative, executive, administrative or advisory body of the
State of Illinois, counties, townships, cities or villages, incorporated towns,
school districts, and all other municipal corporations, boards, bureaus,
committees or commissions of this State, and any subsidiary bodies of any of
the foregoing, including but not limited to committees and subcommittees which
are supported in whole or in part by tax revenue, or which expend tax revenue.
PUBLIC RECORD: Shall have the meaning ascribed to it in the Freedom of
Information Act 1 . (Ord. 84-8-23, 8-20-84)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.
1-12-2: VILLAGE CLERK RESPONSIBLE:
The Village Clerk shall be responsible for administering all requests for
inspection or photocopying of public records. All requests for inspection or
photocopying of public records shall be made in written form on forms provided
by the Village and shall be duly signed by the applicant. The applicant shall
be required to pay to the Village at the time of the request the estimated
costs of any photocopies requested or any other copying requested. No request
shall be considered complete unless and until the amount of the estimated costs
are paid to the Village.
1-12-3: TIME TO RESPOND:
The Village Clerk shall respond to a duly filed request for inspection or
photocopying of public records within seven (7) working days of receipt of the
request. The Village Clerk shall either provide the documents requested within
said seven (7) days for inspection or photocopying, or shall deny the request
if the requested information is not a public record within the meaning of the
Freedom of Information Act. In the event that the Village Clerk cannot comply
with the request for information within the initial seven (7) day period for
any reason permitted by the Freedom of Information Act, the Village Clerk shall
so inform the applicant by letter of his inability to provide that information
within the initial seven (7) working days, and the Clerk shall indicate the
reason for the delay in the letter to the applicant. In the event that a delay
beyond the seven (7) days occurs, the Village Clerk shall fully respond to the
request for inspection or photocopying of public records no later than fourteen
(14) working days after the initial receipt of the completed application for
inspection or photocopying of public records as required by the Freedom of
Information Act.
In the event that the Village Clerk is unable to determine whether or not the
application seeks public records or nonpublic records, the Village Clerk is
authorized to confer with the Village Attorney, or such other persons as are
necessary to make a final determination as to whether or not the request of
information consists of public records within the meaning of the Freedom of
Information Act.
1-12-4: TIME AND PLACE FOR REQUEST FOR RECORDS:
Written requests for inspection or photocopies of public records may be made to
the Village of Riverwoods to the attention of the Village Clerk during normal
office hours, Monday through Friday, eight thirty o'clock (8:30) A.M. to one
thirty o'clock (1:30) P.M. All of said requests for inspection or photocopies
of public records shall be personally delivered to the Village Clerk, or if she
is not present, any other representative of the Village at the Village Hall,
300 Portwine Road, Riverwoods, Illinois.
1-12-5: APPROVAL OF DESCRIPTION OF VILLAGE OF RIVERWOODS:
Section 4 of the Freedom of Information Act requires all public bodies to
display certain information and make the same available to the public for
inspection and copying. The brief description of the Village, the short summary
of its purpose, the block diagram with its functional subdivisions, and the
amount of the operating budget, all of which is set forth in a certain pamphlet
which is on file with the Village Clerk dated July 1, 1984, be and the same is
hereby authorized and approved, and the Village Clerk is authorized and
directed to make the same available to the general public for inspection and
photocopying during normal office hours. (Ord. 84-8-23, 8-20-84; amd. letter,
10-5-89)
1-12-6: EXEMPTIONS:
The following documents, information or materials shall not be considered
records for the purposes of this Chapter:
   A.   Information specifically prohibited from disclosure by Federal or State
law or rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto.
   B.   Information which, if disclosed, would constitute a clearly unwarranted
invasion of personal privacy.
   C.   Investigatory records compiled for State or local administrative law
enforcement purposes or for internal matters of a public body to the extent
that disclosure would 1) interfere with pending or actually and reasonably
contemplated enforcement proceedings, 2) deprive a person of a fair trial or an
impartial hearing, 3) unavoidably disclose the identity of a confidential
source or confidential information furnished only by a confidential source, 4)
disclose unique or specialized investigative techniques other than those
generally used or known, 5) constitute an invasion of personal privacy, or 6)
endanger the life or safety of law enforcement personnel or any other person.
   D.   Criminal history record information obtained by State or local criminal
justice agencies.
   E.   Records of State and local law enforcement agencies and correctional
agencies that are related to the detection and investigation of crime or the
security and operations of correctional institutions.
   F.   Preliminary drafts, notes, recommendations, memoranda and other records
in which opinions are expressed or policies or actions are formulated, and all
other records in which opinions are expressed or policies or actions are
formulated that has not been publicly cited and identified by the Village
President.
   G.   Trade secrets and commercial or financial information obtained from a
person or business when such trade secrets or information are proprietary,
privileged or confidential, or where disclosure of such trade secrets or
information may cause competitive harm.
   H.   Proposal and bids for any contract, grant or agreement which, if
disclosed, would frustrate procurement or give an advantage to any person
proposing to enter into a contract with the Village until an award or final
selection is made.
   I.   Valuable formula, designs, drawings and research data obtained or
produced by any public body when disclosure could reasonably be expected to
produce private gain or public loss.
   J.   Examination data used to administer or determine the qualifications of
an applicant for a license or employment.
   K.   Architect's and engineer's plans for buildings.
   L.   Minutes of the meetings of the Village which are closed to the public.
   M.   Communications between the Village and its attorney or auditor that
would not be subject to discovery in litigation or consists of materials
prepared or compiled by or for the Village in anticipation of a criminal, civil
or administrative proceeding upon the request of any attorney advising the
Village.
   N.   Administrative or technical information associated with data processing
operations which, if disclosed, would jeopardize the security of the system or
data contained therein, or the security of materials exempt under the Freedom
of Information Act.
   O.   Documents or materials relating to collective negotiating matters
between public bodies and their employees or representatives, except that any
final contract or agreement shall be subject to inspection and copying.
   P.   Drafts, notes, recommendations and memoranda pertaining to the
financing and marketing transactions of the public body.
   Q.   The records, documents, and information relating to real estate
purchase negotiations until those negotiations have been completed or otherwise
terminated, and documents and information relating to parcels involved in a
pending or actually and reasonably contemplated eminent domain proceeding.
   R.   Any and all proprietary information and records related to the
operation of an intergovernmental risk management association or self insurance
pool, or jointly self-administered health and accident cooperative or pool.
   S.   Information relating solely to the internal personnel rules and
practices of a public body.
   T.   Information, the disclosure of which is restricted under the Public
Utilities Act.
   U.   Manuals or instruction to staff which relate to the establishment or
collection of liability for any state tax, or which relate to investigations by
a public body to determine violation of any criminal law. (Ord. 84-8-23, 8-20-
84)
1-12-7: APPEAL PERIOD:
Any person whose request for inspection or photocopy of public records is
denied in whole or in part shall have right to appeal the Village Clerk's
decision to the Village President. All appeals shall be taken on the form
provided by the Village, which is available from the Village Clerk at the
Village Hall. Any and all appeals shall be filed with the Village Clerk no
later than fourteen (14) days after the denial by the Village Clerk. In the
event that an appeal is not taken within the fourteen (14) days, the applicant
shall be deemed to have acquiesced in the ruling of the Village Clerk and the
matter shall be deemed concluded.
The Village President shall make a decision as to the appeal and so advise the
applicant by written letter no later than seven (7) working days after the
notice of appeal is properly filed.
1-12-8: COSTS:
The following costs for photocopies of public records shall apply:
   A.   Ten cents ($0.10) per page for all standard eight and one-half inch by
twelve inch (81/2" x 12") pages.
   B.   Actual costs for the reproduction of all oversize documents in the
event that the actual cost is greater than twenty five cents ($0.25) per page,
otherwise twenty five cents ($0.25) per page for oversize documents.
   C.   Certification shall be charged at the rate of one dollar ($1.00) per
page for individual pages, or five dollars ($5.00) for certification of
pamphlets.
1-12-9: APPLICABILITY TO RECORDS RECEIVED OR OBTAINED PRIOR TO JULY 1, 1984:
The Village hereby adopts and approves the foregoing standards, except as
precluded or otherwise prevented by the operation of the Local Records Act, for
the production of public records for all records received or obtained by the
Village prior to July 1, 1984, provided, however, that in addition to the
foregoing costs as set forth in Section
1-12-8, the Village shall further charge an administrative cost of fifteen
dollars ($15.00) per hour for the time expended by the Village Clerk or her
designated assistant in collecting and producing any documents or records that
were received or obtained by the Village prior to July 1, 1984, and such other
and further costs that are actually incurred by the Village in complying with
any requests for said records.
1-12-10: CATEGORIZATION OF RECORDS:
The Village Clerk is authorized and directed to maintain and make available for
inspection and photocopying a reasonably current list of all types or
categories of records under the Village's control. This responsibility shall
apply exclusively to information received after July 1, 1984, and shall not
apply to any records or information received prior to that date.
1-12-11: REVEAL OF EXEMPT RECORDS:
The Village Clerk shall not divulge or reveal to any public record applicant
any records or materials which are exempt from the terms of the Freedom of
Information Act as set forth in section 7 of that Act, unless directed to do so
by a court of competent jurisdiction or the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord.
84-8-23, 8-20-84; amd. letter, 10-5-89)
1-12-12: SEPARABILITY:
It is the intention of the Village Board that this Chapter and every provision
thereof shall be considered separable, and the validity of any section, clause,
provision or part or portion of any section, clause or provision of this
Chapter shall not affect the validity of any portion of the Chapter. (Ord. 84-
8-23, 8-20-84)

MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

1-13-1: Smoking During Public Meetings Prohibited
1-13-2: Alcoholic Liquor In Village Hall

   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke cigars, cigarettes or
pipes in the main meeting hall of the village hall during any period when such
hall is being used for a meeting of the village board, any committee of said

   B.   Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such offense. (Ord. 86-1-2, 1-21-
1986)

Village Hall, 300 Portwine Road, Riverwoods, Illinois 60015, pursuant to such
regulations as the village president from time to time may establish. (Ord. 00-

CHAPTER 14
SYSTEM OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION
SECTION:
1-14-1: Creation Of Administrative Adjudication System
1-14-2: Purpose
1-14-3: Jurisdiction
1-14-4: Administrative Adjudication Division
1-14-5: Hearing Officer
1-14-6: Violation Notice
1-14-7: Service - Due Process
1-14-8: Hearings
1-14-9: Subpoenas
1-14-10: Violations Of Orders
1-14-11: Default
1-14-12: Fines; Compliance Bond
1-14-13: Enforcement Of Hearing Officer's Order
1-14-14: Election Of Remedies
1-14-1: CREATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM:
   A.   Pursuant to the authority of division 2.1 of article 1 of the Illinois
Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1.2-1-1, et seq., and the home
rule powers of the Village, there is hereby created a system of administrative
adjudication of charges of Code violations for the Village. The administrative
hearing system will authorize a Hearing Officer to conduct adjudicatory
hearings of cases instituted by any Village department. The term "this Code"
when used in this chapter refers to the Riverwoods Village Code and the term
"Code violation" or "violation" refers to violations of any ordinance or
regulation of the Village, including, but not limited to, violations of
Building, Property Maintenance, Fire, Life Safety and other national codes and
amendments thereto and the Illinois Vehicle Code, all as adopted by reference
by the Village and as the same from time to time may hereafter be amended.
   B.   The provisions of division 2.1 of article 1 of the Illinois Municipal
Code, as they may be amended from time to time, are hereby adopted and
incorporated into this chapter as if fully set forth herein. In the event of a
conflict between such statutes and this chapter, this chapter will prevail.
   C.   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to administrative
adjudication proceedings to the extent that they are not inconsistent with
other administrative adjudication provisions of this Code, such as the
administrative adjudication proceedings described in title 6, chapter 6,
"Vehicle Seizure And Impoundment", of this Code. (Ord. 17-05-06, 5-16-2017)
1-14-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the administrative adjudication system of charges of Code
violations is to provide a procedure by which charges of Code violations can be
administratively adjudicated equitably and efficiently by administrative
Hearing Officers. The adoption of a system of administrative adjudication shall
not preclude the Village from using other lawful means to enforce and
adjudicate the provisions of any ordinances of the Village. (Ord. 17-05-06, 5-
16-2017)
1-14-3: JURISDICTION:
   A.   Proceeding Initiated: An administrative adjudication proceeding
pursuant to this chapter may be initiated for any alleged Code violations
except that no Code violation shall be prosecuted under such administrative
adjudication proceeding for: 1) an offense where the relief sought is a penalty
of incarceration or a total fine in excess of fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00), excluding allowable costs, 2) an offense that is a traffic
regulation governing the movement of vehicles, and 3) any reportable offenses
under section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. The fifty thousand dollar
($50,000.00) limitation shall not apply to those cases brought to enforce the
collection of any tax imposed and collected by the Village. In addition, any
matter for which the Village President is the designated Hearing Officer under
this Code may be referred to the administrative adjudication system for hearing
and resolution in accordance with this chapter.
   B.   Prosecute Or Refer Offense: The Village may prosecute any of the
offenses listed in subsection G, "Table Of Offenses And Fines", of this
section, by filing a case directly in the appropriate court or the Village may
elect to refer the offense to the administrative adjudication system for
hearing and resolution in accordance with this chapter.
   C.   Settle After Notice: After a notice of any Code violation in the form
of a citation or other charging document ("violation notice" or "citation") is
issued in accordance with this chapter, the person so accused of such
violation, except if the violation citation is marked "must appear", may settle
and compromise the violation claim in respect of such violation by paying to
the Village the applicable amount as shown in violation notice no later than
forty eight (48) hours prior to the date and time set for an administrative
adjudication hearing on the face of the violation notice, subject to the
provisions of subsection
1-14-7B of this chapter.
   D.   Payment: The payment of each citation shall be made in accordance with
the instructions contained in such citation, at the Village Hall address noted
in the citation. The Division of Administrative Adjudication shall issue a
receipt for the money so received and promptly remit said amount to be credited
to the proper Municipal fund. Payment may also be made in accordance with any
other payment options from time to time adopted by the Village.
   E.   Must Appear Offenses: Notwithstanding that an offense may be listed in
subsection G, "Table Of Offenses And Fines", of this section, if the citation
is marked "must appear", then the person alleged to have committed the offense
is required to appear at the administrative adjudication hearing and the
violation is not subject to the pre-pay options as set forth in subsection G,
"Table Of Offenses And Fines", of this section. Citations may be marked "must
appear", among other reasons, for violations that involve corrective actions.
   F.   Penalty Amounts: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code: 1)
all minimum penalty amounts set forth in other sections of this Code, unless
set forth in the fee schedule adopted pursuant to section
1-11-5 of this title, that are in conflict with subsection G, "Table Of
Offenses And Fines", of this section are replaced by the minimum fines set
forth in subsection G, "Table Of Offenses And Fines", of this section and 2) in
all cases where a greater penalty is prescribed by any ordinance of the
Village, including any specific penalties from time to time set forth in the
fee schedule adopted pursuant to section
1-11-5 of this title, such greater penalty shall be controlling over the fines
set forth in subsection G, "Table Of Offenses And Fines", of this section.
(Ord. 17-05-06, 5-16-2017)
