10-2-1: SKETCH PLAN CONFERENCE:
   A.   Application: Prior to the submission of the preliminary plat of any
proposed subdivision, the subdivider may make application to the Board of
Trustees through the Village Clerk to request a meeting with the Plan
Commission to consult with and determine conformity to the Comprehensive Plan,
Official Map, Zoning Ordinance and compliance with this and other applicable
Village ordinances. The subdivider shall file, with the Village Clerk, eleven
(11) copies of the following documents at least ten (10) days prior to a
regularly scheduled Plan Commission meeting, eight (8) copies to be distributed
to the Plan Commission, one to the Village Clerk noting in "Communications
Received", one to the Village Attorney, and one to the Village Engineer.
      1.   Written Notification: To be in the form of a letter of intent from
the subdivider to the Board of Trustees, establishing the subdivider's intent
to develop the land. The letter shall include the following information and
such other material as may be pertinent to the submission:
         a.   Legal description of property encompassing proposed subdivision.
         b.   Names and addresses of the owner(s), including the beneficial
owners under the terms of a land trust, owner of record and the subdivider. The
proof of ownership shall be in the form of a certified copy of a title
insurance policy or a tract search, supplied by a company in the business of
investigating land titles, no more than sixty (60) days old at the time of said
filing. In the event the title appears in the name of a land trust, the trustee
thereof shall certify as to identity each beneficiary of such land trust by
name and address and define his interest therein.
         c.   Land characteristics, existing covenants, location relative to
the existing corporate limits and existing zoning.
         d.   Description of proposed subdivision including number of lots,
typical lot size, gross density, price range and zoning.
      2.   Sketch Plan: A plan that will show, in sketch form, the proposed
layout of streets, lots and other features in relation to existing conditions.
The sketch plan may be a free-hand sketch made directly on a topographic map or
other appropriate medium.
      3.   Tentative Engineering Proposals: With regard to water supply, waste
water facilities, storm drainage and street improvements.
      4.   Sketch Plan Conference Fee: The subdivider shall pay a meeting fee
of two hundred dollars ($200.00) to the Village Clerk for the initial sketch
plan conference meeting. If additional meetings are required, the subdivider
shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each meeting to the Village
Clerk.
   B.   The Plan Commission will discuss the proposed subdivision with the
subdivider and so advise of any Village plan or projects which might affect the
proposed subdivision. The Plan Commission shall review the project with the
subdivider and shall advise the subdivider of the following:
      1.   Procedural steps for platting. (Preliminary plat check list)
      2.   Procedural steps for zoning, if required. (Zoning Ordinance)
      3.   Specific ordinances affecting proposed subdivision. (Zoning
Ordinance, Building Ordinance, Grading Ordinance, etc.)
      4.   Filing and review fees and bonding requirements.
      5.   Other taxing bodies having jurisdiction and the area of
jurisdiction.
The advice provided by the Plan Commission is for information only, and the
subdivider has the burden of assessing the effect of the information on the
proposed subdivision. No formal action shall be taken by the Plan Commission at
the completion of the sketch plan conference. The decision to proceed or
abandon the proposed subdivision rests solely with the subdivider.
10-2-2: PRELIMINARY PLAT:
10-2-2-1: FILING:
Following the sketch plan stage, the subdivider shall submit eighteen (18)
copies of an application in writing for the tentative approval of the
preliminary plat together with the preliminary plat, the supporting
documentation as specified herein or as required during the sketch plan
conference, the filing fee, the meeting fee, and the estimated review fees to
the Village Clerk.
10-2-2-2: FEES:
The fees required shall be paid in cash, by money order, certified or cashier's
check made payable to the "Village of Riverwoods" through the Village Clerk.
These fees shall be as follows:
   A.   Initial Filing Fee:
 
15 lots or less               $150.00
Each lot in excess of 15 lots 10.00
 
   B.   Meeting Fee: A meeting fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per meeting is
required.
   C.   Review Fees: The subdivider shall reimburse the Village for the cost of
the Village Attorney, Village Engineer, Village Forester, Village Planner,
Secretary or Court Reporter, or other persons hired as necessary, incurred in
the review of the preliminary plat and supporting documentation. Estimated
costs of the services required shall be obtained, which the subdivider will
then pay to the Village Clerk prior to the Plan Commission's review and
approval of the preliminary plat. These funds will be placed in an escrow
account by the Village Clerk. Actual costs shall be obtained prior to the
approval of the preliminary plat, and the amount shall be disbursed to the
Village. If a balance remains in the escrow account and the subdivider proceeds
to the final plat, the account shall be left open. If the preliminary plat is
not approved, the remaining funds may be returned to the subdivider.
10-2-2-3: APPLICATION:
The application shall be in the method shown in Form 1 (Chapter 6 of this
Title), eighteen (18) copies to be distributed as follows: Plan Commission,
eight (8); President and Board of Trustees, seven (7); Village Clerk noting in
"Communications Received", one; Village Attorney, one; Village Engineer, one.
The application and other documents shall be filed with the Clerk at least ten
(10) days prior to a regularly scheduled Plan Commission meeting to be
considered at that meeting.
10-2-2-4: FORM AND CONTENT:
The preliminary plat shall be legibly accurately drawn at a scale not smaller
than one hundred feet to the inch (100' = 1"). The preliminary plat shall
contain at least the following information:
   A.   Proposed name of subdivision (not a duplication of any subdivision
heretofore recorded in the Village).
   B.   Legal description of property encompassing proposed subdivision.
   C.   Vicinity map at a scale of not smaller than two thousand feet to the
inch (2,000' = 1") showing existing subdivision, roads, section lines,
corporate limits, and existing utilities in the adjoining areas.
   D.   Names and addresses of the owner, owner of record (including the names
and addresses of all beneficiaries of any land trust, accompanied by a
certified copy of the trust agreement and all amendments thereto), the
subdivider, and designer who prepared the plan. The proof of ownership shall be
in the form of a certified copy of a title insurance policy or a tract search,
supplied by a company in the business of investigating land titles, no more
than sixty (60) days old at the time of said filing. In the event the title
appears in the name of a land trust, the trustee or a beneficiary thereof shall
identify each beneficiary of such land trust by name and address and define his
interest therein.
   E.   Date.
   F.   North point.
   G.   Boundary line of the total area proposed to be subdivided indicated by
solid heavy line and the total approximate acreage encompassed thereby.
   H.   Location, widths and names of all existing or prior platted streets or
other public ways, utility rights of way, parks and other public open spaces,
easements, section lines and Village boundary lines, within or adjacent to the
property. Location of buildings and structures or houses within the property.
   I.   Boundary lines of adjacent parcels of unsubdivided or subdivided land,
showing ownership where possible.
   J.   Existing zoning of proposed subdivision and adjacent property.
   K.   Existing and proposed contours at one foot (1') intervals on USGS
datum.
   L.   Layout and widths of proposed streets with names and the layout and
widths of the crosswalkways and easements.
   M.   Lots intended to be dedicated for public use or set aside for use of
property owners in the subdivision and size thereof.
   N.   Lots showing all dimensions, approximate areas and numbered.
   O.   Building setbacks, showing dimensions.
   P.   Easements to be provided for any and all public utilities. Proper
continuity for the utilities from block to block shall be maintained.
   Q.   Existing sanitary sewers, storm sewers, septic system, drainage
channels, springs, wells (active or inactive), farm drain tiles, water mains,
culverts, or other known underground facilities on the parcel being considered
and on adjacent properties.
   R.   Location and description of all permanent buildings, wooded areas, and
significant topographic and natural features.
   S.   Approval Certificate: The following certificate shall be shown in the
lower right-hand corner of the preliminary plat:
   APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT
The preliminary plat of a subdivision shown hereon has received approval of the
Board of Trustees of the Village of Riverwoods, Illinois, and upon compliance
by the subdivider with requirements of qualifications governing the approval of
the preliminary plats and with other revisions and stipulations that may be
required, the Board of Trustees will receive the final plat for consideration
when submitted by the subdivider in such form and within such time as required
and approved by the Plan Commission.
The Board of Trustees of the Village or Riverwoods, Illinois.
By:                                                                           
Village President Date    Plan Commission Chairman Date
Village Attorney Date   Village Engineer Date
Attest:                        
Village Clerk Date
   T.   Check list signed indicating that all items necessary for review have
been submitted.
10-2-2-5: SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION:
In addition to the requirements set forth in the preceding Section, the
following supplemental information may be required by the Plan Commission.
   A.   Zoning Statement: A statement indicating whether any zoning changes,
variations or special uses will be required. If affirmative, the subdivider
shall list the changes, variations or special uses to be requested. The
subdivider shall submit a petition for such variation in writing to the Village
Clerk for distribution and for recommendation by the Zoning Board of Appeals.
   B.   Boundary survey with angular and linear dimensions.
   C.   Annexation Statement: A statement that the proposed subdivision (where
contiguous) is or is not to be annexed to the Village.
   D.   Soil and Water Conservation District Report: Copies of the report
prepared by the Soil and Water Conservation District as required by Illinois
Statute.
   E.   Erosion Control Statement: A statement that the subdivider will provide
such temporary facilities during construction as are necessary or required to
prevent erosion or the siltation of watercourses, and that adequate measures
will be taken during construction for dust control. The subdivider shall also
agree to clean and restore streams, ditches or watercourses of any kind if
protective measures prove inadequate.
   F.   Proposed covenants and building restrictions.
   G.   Letters of review from all agencies that the subdivider is referred to
in the sketch plan conference.
   H.   Preliminary engineering reports and plans including but not limited to
the consideration of the following:
      1.   Water and waste water facilities, and public utilities.
      2.   Streets and sidewalks, if required.
      3.   Site grading and erosion and siltation control.
      4.   Storm sewers and a drainage plan for the storage and controlled
release of the storm water following a one hundred (100) year frequency storm.
   I.   Soils Report: A soils report, prepared by a professional soils
engineer, of sufficient scope to point out potential ground absorption, runoff,
flooding deficiencies, the presence of unstable soils or of soils of such low
bearing capacity as to constitute problems for conventional construction, or
the presence of subsurface rock that would affect the installation of
underground improvements on the provisions of above ground improvement. If, in
the opinion of the Village Engineer, additional soil investigations, boring or
other soil tests are necessary to determine the nature and extent of such
questionable material, the subdivider shall perform the needed investigations.
The Village Engineer and the Village shall have no liability for costs
connected with the test boring or interpretations of the results of work.
   J.   Demographic Study Requirements: If a school demographic study shall be
submitted, it shall include, but need not be limited to the following:
      1.   The number and types of dwelling units to be constructed, the
density of such dwelling units on the land, and an estimate of each type of
dwelling unit by the number of bedrooms.
      2.   Estimates of the number of children to be generated from the
different types of dwelling units based on general standards used by the school
district in which the subdivision is located.
      3.   Estimates of the number of children to be generated in each school
classification.
   K.   Traffic study, if required by the Plan Commission.
   L.   A letter of approval from the State or County Highway Department shall
be submitted if the project fronts on a County highway. (Per letter dated 2-24-
93)
10-2-2-6: ADDITIONAL INFORMATION 1 :
 
Notes
1 1. Deleted Per letter dated 2-24-93.
10-2-2-7: ACTION BY VILLAGE CLERK:
The Village Clerk shall receive the filing fees and eighteen (18) copies of the
application and supporting documentation, date and distribute as follows: Plan
Commission, eight (8); President and Board of Trustees, seven (7); Village
Attorney, one; Village Engineer, one; one copy to be noted in "Communications
Received" and retained for Village files. The Village Clerk shall also inform
the subdivider of the date, time and place of the meeting at which the Plan
Commission will review the submission.
10-2-2-8: ACTION BY PLAN COMMISSION:
The Plan Commission shall approve or disapprove the application for preliminary
approval of a plat within ninety (90) days from the date of the application or
the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting data,
whichever date is later, unless such time is extended by mutual consent. If
such plat is disapproved, then within said ninety (90) days the Plan Commission
shall furnish the applicant in writing a statement setting forth the reason for
disapproval and specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed
plat fails to conform to the ordinances, including Official Map.
   A.   Make Recommendations: Approve or disapprove the proposed preliminary
plat and submit its written recommendations, including the recommendations of
the Village Engineer and Village Attorney, to the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Advise Subdivider: If the Plan Commission finds that changes, additions
or corrections are required on the preliminary plat, the Plan Commission shall
so advise the subdivider. The subdivider may resubmit the preliminary plat to
the Plan Commission, paying a fifty dollar ($50.00) meeting fee, for
consideration at the next regular meeting.
   The resubmission of a preliminary plat shall be considered a new submission
to establish the time for review.
   C.   Attendance at Plan Commission Meetings: The Plan Commission need not
review a preliminary plat unless the subdivider or his authorized agent is
present at the meeting, except when prior approval has been given by the Plan
Commission.
   D.   Notification to Subdivider: The Plan Commission shall not be obliged to
give official written notification of Plan Commission action to the subdivider.
10-2-2-9: ACTION BY VILLAGE BOARD:
If such plat is approved by the Plan Commission, the Village Board shall accept
or reject said plat within thirty (30) days after its next regular scheduled
meeting following the action of the Plan Commission. Provided, however,
preliminary approval shall not qualify a plat for recording. The preliminary
plat, as submitted to the Board of Trustees, must have designated thereon the
words "This is a Preliminary Plat, of no Legal Effect, and Not to be Recorded".
Acceptance of the preliminary plat shall become effective only after the
"Approval of Preliminary Plat" certificates on the preliminary plan are signed
and dated. The Village Clerk shall return to the subdivider one of the two (2)
signed copies of the preliminary plat and the other copy shall be returned to
the Plan Commission. The Village Clerk shall also submit to the subdivider a
check list for the final plat, Form 4 (shown in Chapter 6 of this Title).
10-2-2-10: QUALIFICATIONS OF APPROVAL:
The following qualifications shall govern approval of the preliminary plat:
   A.   Approval of a preliminary plat by the Plan Commission and the Board of
Trustees is tentative, only, involving merely the general acceptability of the
layout as submitted, and shall not qualify the plat for recording.
   B.   Approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of one
year. Upon application of the subdivider, the Board of Trustees may grant an
extension. The application for said extension shall not require an additional
filing fee.
   C.   Approval of the preliminary plat shall not be made until reimbursement
is made from the escrow account to the Village for expenses incurred in review
of the preliminary plat and supporting documentation.
10-2-3: FINAL PLAT:
10-2-3-1: FILING:
Following approval of the preliminary plat by the Board of Trustees, the
subdivider shall submit to the Village Clerk for distribution at least ten (10)
days prior to the Plan Commission meeting:
   A.   Eighteen (18) copies of each of the following, to be distributed as
follows: Plan Commission, eight (8); President and Board of Trustees, seven
(7); Village Attorney, one; Village Engineer, one; one copy to be noted in
"Communications Received" and retained for the Village files:
      1.   Application for final plat, Form 3 (shown in Chapter 6 of this
Title).
      2.   Final plat of proposed subdivision.
   B.   Three (3) copies of each of the following to be distributed to the Plan
Commission:
      1.   Plans and specifications of the improvements required therein.
      2.   Agreements.
      3.   Completion guarantee.
      4.   Bond.
      5.   Current title commitment.
   C.   Review Fees: Estimated costs for review of the final plat shall be
obtained from the Village Engineer and Village Attorney. Estimated review costs
shall be required of the subdivider and held in an escrow account until such
payment is required. Payment from the escrow account to the Village shall be
made prior to approval of the final plat.
10-2-3-2: ACREAGE FEE:
At the time of approval of the final plat and before the recording and filing
of the approved final plat of subdivision, an acreage fee of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) per acre or portion thereof shall be paid by the subdivider
to the Village.
10-2-3-3: CONFORMANCE WITH PRELIMINARY PLAT:
The final plat shall conform substantially to the approved preliminary plat. It
may, with the Board of Trustees' consent, constitute only that portion of the
approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposes to record and develop
it that time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to all requirements
of these regulations.
10-2-3-4: FILING PERIOD:
The final plat shall be filed with the Board of Trustees not later than twelve
(12) months after the date of approval of the preliminary plat; otherwise the
preliminary plat will be considered void unless an extension is requested by
the subdivider in writing and granted in writing by the Board of Trustees.
10-2-3-5: FORM AND CONTENT:
The final plat shall be accurately drawn in ink on tracing cloth or mylar
drafting film, in a manner that clear and legible transparent or contact prints
or photostatic copies can be made. The final plat shall be at a scale of one
hundred feet to the inch (100' = 1") on sheets not to exceed twenty four inches
by thirty six inches (24" x 36"). Where necessary, the plat may be drawn on
several sheets accompanied by an index sheet showing the entire subdivision.
The final plat shall show the following:
   A.   Name of subdivision.
   B.   Legal description of property encompassing the subdivision. (Ord. 272,
3-20-78)
   C.   Names and addresses of the owner, owner of record (including the names
and addresses of all beneficiaries of any land trust, accompanied by a
certified copy of the trust agreement and all amendments thereto), the
subdivider, and designer who prepared the plan. The proof of ownership shall be
in the form of a certified copy of a title insurance policy or a tract search,
supplied by a company in the business of investigating land titles, no more
than sixty (60) days old at the time of said filing. In the event the title
appears in the name of a land trust, the trustee or a beneficiary thereof shall
identify each beneficiary of such land trust by name and address and define his
interest therein. (Ord. 79-3-6, 3-19-79)
   D.   Scale, one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100') shown graphically.
   E.   Date.
   F.   North point.
   G.   Boundary of plat, based upon an accurate traverse, with angular and
lineal dimensions.
   H.   Exact location, width and name of all streets within and adjoining the
plat, and the exact location and widths of all crosswalkways.
   I.   Distances to the nearest established street lines or official monuments
(not less than 3) which shall be accurately described on the plat.
   J.   Township and section lines and Municipal boundaries accurately tied to
the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles.
   K.   Radii, internal angles, points of curvature, tangent lengths, and
bearings and lengths of all arcs.
   L.   All easements provided for public services, drainage and utilities.
   M.   Layout, numbers, dimensions and size of lots, in square feet. When lots
are located on a curve, the lot width at the building setback line shall be
shown. Street address for each lot.
   N.   Accurate location of all monuments which shall be concrete with iron
pipe cased in center. A minimum of two (2) such monuments shall be set at the
opposite extremities of the subdivision. Iron pipe stakes, a minimum length of
twenty four inches (24"), shall be set at all lot corners, at each end of all
curves, at all angle points in any line, at all angle points along a meander
line, the points to be not less than twenty feet (20') back from the normal
water elevation of a lake or from the bank of a stream, except that when such
corners or points fall within a street, or proposed future street, then such
pipes shall be set at such actual corners. All U.S., State, County or other
official bench marks, monuments or triangulation stations in or adjacent to the
property shall be preserved in precise position.
   O.   Lot or lots to be dedicated or reserved for public use, with the
purposes indicated thereon, and of any lot or lots to be reserved by deed
covenant for common ownership and use of all property owners.
   P.   Building setback lines accurately shown with dimensions.
   Q.   Protective covenants which shall be lettered on the final plat, or on
an attached document in form for recording. (See Form 6 as shown in Chapter 6
of this Title, and reference in Section
10-3-4C of this Title.)
   R.   Listing of all public authorities having jurisdiction thereof.
   S.   Owner's (and, if required, any mortgage holder of record) certificate
to the effect that he has caused the land described to be subdivided along with
a notary certificate of owner's signature.
   T.   Need to include notary certificate.
   U.   President and Board of Trustees' certificate approving and accepting
the plat attested by the Village Clerk.
   V.   Recorder's certificate certifying that the final plat is recorded in
the County of Lake.
   W.   Surveyor's certificate to the effect that he has surveyed and
subdivided the property and the plat represents a true and accurate
representation of said survey and subdivision.
   X.   Plan Commission certificate approving the plat.
   Y.   County Clerk certificate to the effect that there are no taxes against
any land included in the plat.
   Z.   Special assessment.
   AA.   Village Engineer's certificate to certify that all of the improvements
meet the standards of all Village ordinances, certifies that the final plat
conforms with the preliminary plan and includes the proper easements.
   BB.   Village Attorney's certificate certifies that the improvement security
is in the proper form and amount, checks the final plat and all accompanying
documents.
   CC.   Certificate of easements for all public utilities and such other
disclosures.
   DD.   Such other certificates as may be required by Illinois State Statutes.
10-2-3-6: SUPPLEMENTAL DOCUMENTS:
The final plat to be filed of record shall be accompanied by the following
documents:
   A.   Plans and specifications and cost estimates for all improvements in
accordance with the standards herein or as required during the review of the
preliminary plat. The Village Engineer shall certify by signing the plat that
the improvements described in the subdivider's plans and specifications meet
the minimum requirements of all ordinances of the Village prior to any action
by the Plan Commission.
   B.   A letter of approval from the State or County Highway Department shall
be submitted if the project fronts on a County highway.
   C.   IEPA permit applications requiring Village signature such as water and
sanitary sewer shall be submitted completely filled out ready for the Village
signature, and sent to the Village Engineer for approval.
   D.   Current title commitment showing ownership, liens and encumbrances.
   E.   A subdivision improvement deposit in an amount equal to one hundred
twenty five percent (125%) of the estimated cost of improvements shall be
placed in escrow in accordance with the terms of the escrow agreement contained
in Appendix II (shown in Chapter 6 of this Title) for the purpose of:
      1.   To pay the actual costs of construction of the subdivision
improvements.
      2.   To pay the engineering and inspection fees of the Village.
      3.   To pay the cost of maintaining the subdivision improvements and
repair to existing improvements and damage caused by making the aforesaid
subdivision improvements for a period of two (2) years after acceptance.
      4.   Any other customary expenses of the developer in meeting any
requirements of the Village pertaining to the subdivision.
   F.   A subdivider may elect to deposit an amount equal to one hundred twenty
five percent (125%) of the estimated cost of improvements directly with the
Village. The Village, upon the certification of the Village Engineer that the
improvements have been completed or partially completed, will pay to the
contractor, in not more than three (3) payments, the amount due under the
contract. The Village will also make the distribution of funds from the deposit
for the fees and cost of:
      1.   Engineering and inspection.
      2.   Maintaining the subdivision improvements for a period of two (2)
years after acceptance, and to repair any damage done to existing improvements
caused by making the aforesaid subdivision improvements.
      3.   Any other costs or expenses in meeting the requirements of the
Village.
Nothing in this subsection will relieve the subdivider of bearing the full cost
for the subdivision improvements and expenses required by the Village.
   G.   After completion and acceptance of the subdivision improvements, the
Village will authorize the refund of any residue remaining, except for ten
percent (10%) of the original deposit or the amount stipulated in the escrow
agreement. The retained amount shall be used for maintenance of the
improvements for a period of two (2) years after the date of acceptance and
then any balance remaining will be refunded.
   H.   The subdivider shall secure and maintain such insurance from an
insurance company authorized to write casualty insurance in the State where the
work is located as will protect himself, his subcontractors, the Village and
the Engineer and his employees from claims from bodily injury, death or
property damage which may arise from subdividing the property. The subdivider
shall not commence work until he has obtained all insurance required under this
paragraph and shall have filed the certificate of insurance or the certified
copy of the insurance policy with the Village. Each insurance policy shall
contain a clause providing that it shall not be canceled by the insurance
company without ten (10) days' written notice to the Village of intention to
cancel. The amount of such insurance shall be not less than the following:
      1.   Workmen's compensation and employer's liability insurance shall be
secured and maintained as required by the State.
      2.   Public liability, bodily injury and property damage:
         a.   Injury or death of one person -- $500,000.00.
         b.   Injury to more than one person in a single accident -
- $1,000,000.00.
         c.   Property damage -- $250,000.00.
      3.   Automobile and truck public liability, bodily injury and property
damage:
         a.   Injury or death of one person -- $500,000.00.
         b.   Injury to more than one person -- $1,000,000.00.
         c.   Property damage -- $250,000.00.
   I.   Indemnity: The subdivider shall indemnify and save harmless the Village
and the Engineer and his employees from and against all losses and all claims,
demands, payments, suits, actions, recoveries and judgments of every nature and
description brought or recovered against him by reason of any omission or act
of the subdivider, his agents or employees in the execution of the work or in
the guarding of it. The subdivider shall obtain in the name of the Village and
shall maintain and pay the premiums for such insurance in such amount and with
such provisions as will protect the Village from contingent liability and a
copy of such insurance policy or policies shall be delivered to the Village.
Full compliance by the Village with the terms and provisions of such insurance
policy or policies shall be a condition precedent to the Village's right to
enforce against the subdivider any provisions of this Chapter.
   J.   Fire Insurance: In addition to such fire insurance as the subdivider
elects to carry for his own protection, he shall secure and maintain in the
name of the Village policies upon such structures and material and in such
amounts as shall be designated. The policies shall be secured from a company
which is satisfactory to the Village and delivered to the Village.
10-2-3-7: QUALIFICATIONS GOVERNING APPROVAL:
The final plat to be placed on record shall be approved, subject to the
following conditions:
   A.   Recorded as prescribed herein.
   B.   The approval of the final plat shall not be deemed to constitute or
effect an acceptance by the public of the dedication of any street or other
proposed public way or space shown on the plat.
10-2-3-8: ACTION BY VILLAGE CLERK:
The Village Clerk shall receive eighteen (18) copies of the final plat and
supplemental documents. Distribution shall be as outlined in Section
10-2-3-1 of this Chapter. The Village Clerk shall also inform the subdivider of
the date, time and place of the meeting at which the Plan Commission will
review the submission. At such time as the preliminary plat is approved, the
Village Clerk shall attach a certified copy of the order or resolution of
approval to a copy of the plat. If the proposed plat is disapproved, the order
or resolution shall state the reasons for the disapproval, specifying with
particularity the aspects in which the proposed plat fails to conform to the
Official Map. A copy of the order or resolution shall be filed in the office of
the Village Clerk.
10-2-3-9: ACTION BY PLAN COMMISSION:
When a person submitting a plat of subdivision or resubdivision for final
approval has supplied all drawings, maps and other documents required by the
Municipal ordinances to be furnished in support thereof, and if all such
material meets all Municipal requirements, the Plan Commission shall approve
the proposed plat within thirty (30) days of the date of filing the last
required document or other paper or within thirty (30) days from the date of
filing application for final approval of the plat, whichever date is later. The
applicant and the Plan Commission may mutually agree to extend the thirty (30)
day period. When the Plan Commission approves, as aforesaid, it shall fix upon
the plat the certifying signature of its chairman and forthwith deliver the
plat to the Village Clerk for final consideration and approval by the Board of
Trustees.
10-2-3-10: ACTION BY BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
Within thirty (30) days from the date of the approval of the plat by the Plan
Commission, or within such additional time as the applicant and the Board of
Trustees may mutually agree upon, the Board of Trustees shall consider the
final plat, and if the person submitting the plat for final approval has
supplied all drawings, maps and other documents required by the Municipal
ordinances to be furnished in support thereof, and if all such material meets
all Municipal requirements, the Board of Trustees shall approve the proposed
final plat within the aforesaid thirty (30) days. (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
10-2-3-11: ESCROW DEPOSITS:
Prior to initial consideration by the Board of Trustees of the Village of an
annexation agreement, a plat of subdivision or a request for zoning variation
which will require review by either or both the Village Attorney and the
Village Engineer or which may require publication of legal notices, an initial
minimum escrow deposit of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for a commercial
development or one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a residential development
shall be made with the Village Treasurer. Said deposit may be set at a higher
amount if deemed necessary by the Building Chairman and the Finance Chairman.
In no event shall the deposit be set at a lower amount unless approved by a
two-thirds (2/3) majority of the Board of Trustees.
Petitioner may be required to deposit additional funds to cover expenses
incurred by the Village relating to their petition. Requests for additional
deposits must be complied with within ten (10) working days from the date of
request or petitioner will be deemed as having withdrawn his petition. (Ord.
85-7-40, 7-16-85)
10-2-3-12: FILING OF PLATS:
Upon approval by the Board of Trustees, the Village Clerk shall give the
original and two (2) copies thereof to the Village Attorney who shall
immediately record the plat with the Recorder of Lake County. The Village
Attorney shall thereupon give a copy of the recorded plat to the subdivider and
the original copy to the Village Clerk for filing in the Village records. The
subdivider shall reimburse the Village for any fees incurred. (Ord. 272, 3-20-
78)
CHAPTER 3
PLANNING STANDARDS
SECTION:
10-3-1: Block Standards
10-3-2: Lot Standards
10-3-3: Easements
10-3-4: Street Standards
10-3-5: Alleys
10-3-6: Public Sidewalks and Pedestrian Ways
10-3-1: BLOCK STANDARDS:
   A.   Configuration, General: The shape of blocks shall be determined by
topographical features, the basic street system and traffic pattern, lot
depths, and areas designated for public and other nonresidential land uses. In
addition to these, the lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined
with due regard to:
      1.   Site Adequacy: Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the
special needs of the type of use contemplated.
      2.   Zoning: Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions. 1
      3.   Convenience: Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and
safety of street traffic.
   B.   Length:
      1.   Residential Subdivisions: The block length shall be as recommended
by the Plan Commission and approved by the Village Board.
      2.   Nonresidential Subdivisions: The block length shall be as
recommended by the Plan Commission and approved by the Village Board.
   C.   Configuration, Nonresidential:
      1.   Blocks intended for business or industrial use must be designated as
such, and the plan must show adequate off-street areas to provide for parking,
loading docks and such other facilities as may be required to accommodate motor
vehicles.
      2.   In front of areas zoned or designated for business use the street
width and the roadway widths shall be increased on the side or sides on which
the property for commercial use is located by a merging lane at least eleven
feet (11') wide to insure the free flow of traffic without interference by
vehicles entering or leaving parking areas. This is not to be considered a part
of the parking area herein required. It is intended that where the abutting
property on both sides of a street is developed for commercial use there shall
be two (2) such lanes in addition to the minimum required street width.
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 9 of this Code.
10-3-2: LOT STANDARDS:
   A.   Configuration of Lots: The lot size, width, depth, shape and
orientation shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for
the type of development and use contemplated. Due regard shall be shown for all
natural features, such as tree growth, watercourses, historic spots, or similar
conditions which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the
proposed development.
   B.   Conformance With Zoning Regulations: Width and area of lots shall
conform to or exceed the lot width and area requirements set forth in the
Zoning Ordinance of the Village (Title 9 of this Code) or that of the
appropriate County in the unincorporated areas beyond the Village limits,
except that subdivisions contiguous to the Village shall conform to all
applicable requirements of the Village Zoning Ordinance. Corner lots shall be
sufficiently larger than interior lots to allow maintenance of building lines
on both sides fronting on a street.
   C.   Nonresidential Lots: Width, area and depth of lots in an industrial or
business subdivision shall be as recommended by the Plan Commission and
approved by the Board of Trustees.
   D.   Adequate Building Site Required: Lots abutting a watercourse, drainage
way, channel or stream shall have additional minimum width and depth as
required to provide an adequate building site and afford the minimum usable
area required in the Zoning Ordinance (Title 9 of this Code) for front, rear
and side yards, as recommended by the Plan Commission. (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
   E.   Through Lots: The platting of new through lots is forbidden, except
where the front yards of such lots abut a minor street and the rear yards of
such lots back upon a primary or secondary street, and where vehicular access
is provided only from the minor street; or except as a special use subject to
Section
9-11-9 of the Zoning Title. The Village Board shall determine which street
frontage is the front and which is the rear for existing vacant through lots,
based on the characteristics of adjacent streets, the compatibility of nearby
properties and the wishes of the owner of the property. In every zoning
district the rear of each through lot shall be subject to the minimum front
yard building setback required in that district. (Ord. 95-9-12, 9-19-95)
   F.   Driveway Location: Lots shall be arranged to provide for a minimum of
driveway openings on primary and secondary streets. Driveway locations on
corner lots shall be indicated on the final plat and the location shown shall
appear as a covenant running with that lot.
   G.   Frontage: All lots shall front on a private road easement or publicly
dedicated street, as recommended by the Plan Commission. (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
10-3-3: EASEMENTS:
   A.   Public Utility Easements: Utility distribution or transmission
installations serving the subdivision may be located in underground easements
and so designated on the subdivision plat of record. Such easements may be
located along the rear lot lines, side lot lines or front lot lines. They shall
occupy not less than twenty feet (20') of which ten feet (10') may be shown on
each of two (2) adjacent lots. Public utility easements, including but not
limited to telephone, electricity, gas, sewer, water, TV cables, and drainage
shall be indicated as such on the final plat and shall not be used for drainage
purposes, except that they may be graded as a drainage swale.
   B.   Drainage Easements: Where a subdivision is transversed by a
watercourse, drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a
drainage easement or right of way conforming substantially with the lines of
such watercourse, and further width as will be necessary for the purpose of
adequately maintaining or improving the watercourse. Said easements shall not
be used for any other purposes, except that utilities may cross this easement;
provided, that the crossing does not alter the intended use of the easement.
The size of the easement shall be recommended by the Plan Commission and
Village Engineer.
   C.   Village Utility Easements: Whenever it is necessary to install water
main, sanitary sewer, storm sewers or other underground utilities to be
maintained by the Village in areas other than public rights of way, easements
shall be established and so designated. Easements may not be less than twenty
feet (20') wide, ten feet (10') of which may be shown on each of two (2)
adjacent lots.
Whenever the Village utilities and the public utilities follow a common route,
they may be in a common easement termed a utility easement. Said easements
shall be of adequate width for the purpose intended, but in no case shall it be
less than twenty feet (20').
   D.   Continuity Of Easements: Easements shall be designed to provide
continuity throughout the entire subdivision. (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
10-3-4: STREET STANDARDS:
   A.   Street Arrangements: All streets shall be on private easements, unless
otherwise recommended by the Plan Commission. Where such is not shown on the
Official Map, the arrangement of streets within a subdivision shall:
      1.   Continuity: Provide for the continuation or projection of existing
principal streets in adjacent areas, or conform to a plan for the area or
neighborhood approved or adopted by the Plan Commission to meet a particular
situation where topographical or other conditions make continuance or
conformance to existing streets impracticable.
      2.   Street Jogs: Avoid street jogs with center line offsets of less than
one hundred twenty five feet (125') unless required to conform to a street
plan.
      3.   Intersections: Evidence that all street intersections and
confluences encourage safe and efficient traffic flow and, in general, are at
right angles. Only three-way intersections shall be permitted unless otherwise
recommended by the Plan Commission.
      4.   Residence Serving: Provide that streets serving principally
residences shall be laid out so their use by through traffic will be
discouraged.
   B.   Street Names: Street names shall not duplicate, nor be confused with,
the names of existing streets. (Existing street names must be projected
wherever possible, and all street names are subject to approval of the Board of
Trustees.)
   Streets shall not contain reserve strips controlling access to public
utilities, streets or alleys.
   C.   Covenants And Restrictions: Where private road easements are utilized,
there shall be provided a declaration of covenants and restrictions providing
for the maintenance of said streets by the property owners. The executed
declaration of covenants and restrictions shall accompany the final plat of the
subdivision. (See Form 6, As shown in Chapter 6 of this Title.)
   D.   Minimum Street Standards:
      1.   Minimum Dimensions: All road easements or rights of way for streets
shall conform to the following minimum dimensions:
         a.   Primary Streets: Conform to major street plan, but in no instance
less than eighty feet (80') in width.
         b.   Secondary Streets: Not less than eighty feet (80') in width.
         c.   Minor Streets: (See tables in subsection
10-5-2B).
         d.   Cul-De-Sac Streets: (See tables in subsection
10-5-2B).
         e.   Frontage Roads: Not less than forty feet (40') in width.
         f.   Bike Paths And Walkways: Not less than ten feet (10') in width.
         g.   Alley: Not less than twenty feet (20') in width.
      2.   Visibility: Clear visibility, measured along the center line of the
street, shall be provided for at least three hundred feet (300') on all primary
streets, and at least one hundred feet (100') on all other streets.
      3.   Alleys: Alleys are not permitted, except where recommended by the
Plan Commission and Board of Trustees.
      4.   Cul-De-Sacs: Cul-de-sac streets are encouraged.
      5.   Frontage Roads: Where property to be subdivided is zoned or is
planned to be zoned industrial or business and said property borders on or
contains an existing or proposed primary street where access is or may be
limited in the future, the Plan Commission may require a frontage road.
   Right-of-way widths for frontage roads, when required, shall be in addition
to the adjacent trafficway and planting strip.
   Points of access from the frontage road to the primary street shall be
spaced at a minimum of one thousand three hundred twenty feet (1,320'). A
planting strip having a minimum width of twenty feet (20') shall be provided
between the pavement of the arterial street and the pavement of the frontage
road.
      6.   Partial Streets: Partial streets shall be prohibited. Where a
dedicated partial street exists adjacent to the parcel being subdivided, the
other half shall be platted and improved according to the standards contained
herein.
   Where the dedication of a right of way is required on land not wholly owned
by the developer, the Trustees may take such action as is required to secure
said rights of way and the developer shall pay such costs as well as the cost
of the required improvements.
      7.   Horizontal Alignment: When there is an angle of deflection of more
than ten degrees (10°) between two (2) center line tangent sections of a
street, a curve of two hundred feet (200') minimum radius shall connect them.
      8.   Vertical Alignment: At all changes in grade, a vertical curve shall
be introduced. The length of the curve shall be in accordance with the type and
use of the street.
   E.   Street Design: Street design and geometrics not covered in this Section
shall be in accordance with applicable standards of the Illinois Department of
Transportation and American Association of State Highway Officials "Urban
Highways and Arterial Streets". (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
   F.   Frontage: When a frontage requirement is set forth in any applicable
ordinance in the Village with respect to a street, said street must serve at
least three (3) or more lots of record. (Ord. 88-11-22, 11-15-88)
10-3-5: ALLEYS:
   A.   In commercial, business and industrial districts, definite and assured
provisions shall be made for service access such as off- street loading,
unloading and parking consistent and adequate for the uses proposed. If in the
opinion of the Plan Commission such facilities are not adequate, the Plan
Commission may permit or require the dedication and improvement of a public
alley.
   B.   Alleys in residential areas are not permitted.
   C.   Sharp changes and dead-ends in alley alignment shall be avoided. (Ord.
272, 3-20-78)
10-3-6: PUBLIC SIDEWALKS AND PEDESTRIAN WAYS:
   A.   The Plan Commission may recommend that sidewalks be provided where
considered necessary to public safety due to anticipated concentration of
pedestrian traffic.
   B.   Pedestrianways or crosswalks with not less than a ten foot (10') right
of way, not necessarily paved, may be required near the center of any block in
excess of one thousand feet (1,000') in length when recommended by the Plan
Commission and approved by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
CHAPTER 4
SCHOOL, PARK AND PUBLIC LAND SITES
SECTION:
10-4-1: General
10-4-2: Parks, Preserves And Other Public Areas
10-4-3: School District Agreements
10-4-1: GENERAL:
As a condition of approval of a final plat of the subdivision, each subdivider
of more than six (6) acres shall be required to dedicate land for a school
site, park site or other public land to serve the immediate and future needs of
the residents of the development; or cash contributions in lieu of actual land
dedication; or a combination of both, at the option of the Village in
accordance with the following criteria and formula:
The Comprehensive Plan 1  shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. (Ord.
272, 3-20-78)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 9, Chapter 1 of this Code.
10-4-2: PARKS, PRESERVES AND OTHER PUBLIC AREAS:
   A.   Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate density of a proposed
development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for
dedication. The total requirement shall be one acre of land per one hundred
fifty (150) of ultimate population in accordance with the following standards
by types of recreational and park areas:
      1.   Neighborhood Park: Minimum one acre.
      2.   Village-Wide Recreational Park: Minimum five (5) acres.
   B.   Population Formula: The formula used shall be four and four- tenths
(4.4) population per lot.
   C.   Location:
      1.   Neighborhood parks are to be located within the subdivision or added
to another adjacent subdivision.
      2.   Village-wide parks shall be located in accordance with the
requirements of the Comprehensive Plan or as recommended by the Plan Commission
and approved by the Board of Trustees.
   D.   Credit for Private Open Spaces and Recreational Areas: When subdividers
provide their own space for recreation areas and facilities, it has the effect
of reducing the demand for local public recreational services. Depending on the
size of the subdivision, a portion of the park and recreation area in the
subdivision may, at the option of the Board of Trustees, be provided in the
form of "private" open space in lieu of dedicated "public" open space. The
extent of same shall be determined by the Board of Trustees, based upon the
needs projected by residents and in conformance to the total park and
recreation land for the general area.
   E.   Criteria for Requiring a Cash Contribution in Lieu of Land Dedication:
Where the subdivision is small and the resulting site is too small to be
practical or where the available land is inappropriate for school site, park
site or other public use, the Village may require the subdivider to pay a cash
contribution in lieu of land dedication. The cash contribution in lieu of land
dedication shall be held by the Village solely for the acquisition of a school
site, park site or public land facilities or buildings which will be available
to serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of that subdivision and
the general Village residents or for the improvement of other existing public
land which already serves such needs. This contribution shall be designated by
the Board of Trustees for a specific use within ten (10) years of the
completion of the subdivision. (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
      Fair Market Value: The cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based
on the "fair market value" of the acres of land in the area improved as
specified herein, that otherwise would have been dedicated as park and
recreation sites. It has been determined that the present "fair market value"
of such improved land in and surrounding the Village is two hundred thousand
dollars ($200,000.00) per acre and such figure shall be used in making any
calculation herein unless the subdivider files a written objection thereto. In
the event of any such objection, the subdivider shall submit an appraisal
showing the "fair market value" of such improved land in the area of his
development or other evidence thereof and final determination of said "fair
market value" per acre of such improved land shall be made by the Board of
Trustees based upon such information submitted by the subdivider. (Ord. 272, 3-
20-78; amd. Ord. 88-2-6, 2-16-88; Ord. 90-5-3, 5-15-90)
   F.   Criteria for Requiring Land Dedication and a Contribution: There may be
situations where it will be necessary to require a combination of land
dedication and a contribution to meet the needs of this Chapter. Such
recommendations shall be made by the Plan Commission and approved by the Board
of Trustees.
   G.   Reservation of Additional Land: Where the development plan or the
requirements of the Village call for a larger amount of park and recreational
land in a particular subdivision than the developer is required to dedicate,
the land needed beyond the developer's contribution shall be reserved for
subsequent purchase by the Village or other public body designated by the
Village; provided, that such acquisition is made within one year from the date
of approval of the final plat, or an agreement between the developer and the
Village is recorded outlining specific conditions for the conveyance of such
property.
   H.   Combining With Adjoining Developments: Where the subdivision is less
than forty (40) acres, public open space which is to be dedicated should, where
possible, be combined with dedications from adjoining subdivisions in order to
produce useable recreation areas without hardship on a particular subdivider.
   I.   Topography and Grading: The slope, topography and geology of the
dedicated site as well as its surroundings must be suitable for its intended
purposes.
   J.   Improvement of Sites: Park and recreational sites shall be dedicated
fully developed ready for use. Fully developed shall mean all site grading
including surface drainage and seeding and sodding required for the intended
use, but not including final development such as baseball, tennis or like
facilities nor any structures. Fully developed shall also mean providing
adequate access to and fully developed perimeter streets. (Ord. 272, 3-20-1978)
10-4-3: SCHOOL DISTRICT AGREEMENTS:
The subdivider shall meet with the affected school district or districts and
determine the needs based on the demographic study which may be required to be
submitted with the preliminary plat. As a condition of approval of the final
plat, a letter of agreement between the school district and/or districts and
the subdivider shall be forwarded to the Plan Commission for their
recommendation to the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 272, 3-20-1978)
CHAPTER 5
REQUIRED LAND IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
10-5-1: General Statements
10-5-2: Street Improvements
10-5-3: Streetlights
10-5-4: Methods Of Construction For Required Underground Improvements
10-5-5: Utility Improvements
10-5-6: Sanitary Sewer And Water Main Specifications
10-5-7: Storm Drainage
10-5-8: Site Grading Plan
10-5-9: Public Utilities
10-5-10: Landscaping
10-5-11: Street Name Signs
10-5-12: General Standards Of Design And Construction; Parking Lot And Sidewalk
Standards
10-5-13: Inspection Required
10-5-14: Acceptance
10-5-15: Cost Of Oversize Improvements
10-5-16: Construction Inspection Fees
10-5-17: Erosion And Sedimentation Control
10-5-1: GENERAL STATEMENTS:
   A.   No subdivision of land shall be approved by the Village Board unless
and until plans and specifications incorporating all improvements required
under this Title are reviewed and approved by the Village Attorney and
Engineer.
   B.   The Board of Trustees may, from time to time, adopt as standards
certain specifications and details supplementing and clarifying this Title or
other ordinances of the Village. Such specifications and details, when adopted,
shall be printed and made available for inspection and purchase.
   C.   In addition to the requirements contained herein, the subdivider shall
comply with all applicable provisions of the Zoning Ordinance (Title 9 of this
Code), Official Map and Comprehensive Plan of the Village and such other
ordinances as are applicable.
   D.   Natural Growth Areas: The Village has special interest in preserving
the natural environs and creating subdivisions which attempt to look wooded and
natural rather than open and developed. Therefor, the subdivider shall do all
that is necessary in designing and improving the subdivision so that the land
is changed to this goal. Trees and shrubs must be preserved and new growth of
trees and shrubs should be included and incorporated in the final plat
improvement. In all cases strict adherence to Title 8, Chapter 5 of this Code,
Land Grading and Erosion Control, is required and said provisions used as
guidelines. Consultation with the Village Forester is encouraged.
   E.   Hazard Areas: During land improvements the subdivider is to protect the
public from injury by covering, fencing, posting or shielding any area that is
open or hazardous.

   A.   Minimum and Maximum Street Grades: All street grades shall be in

   C.   Soils Report: Soils reports may be required. A profile of the
subsurface conditions shall be provided to a depth as recommended by the
Village Engineer. The soils profile shall show the types of soils, natural
moisture content, unconfined compression strength, ground water data, and frost
susceptible material. IBR values shall be made available to the Village for
checking the roadway design, if required.
   D.   Minimum Bituminous Concrete Surface and Flexible Base Thicknesses:
Surface and base course materials indicated in Table IV will be permitted for
the construction of roadways within the Village. No roadway shall be built with
less than the specified thicknesses, regardless of the number of movements
projected or the IBR values of the soil. (Ord. 272, 3-20-78)
